guide.title: Logging Configuration Guide for Gentoo Infrastructure Servers
guide.abstract: This guide documents how logging should be configured on Gentoo Infrastructure servers.

body.p: sysklogd is required to be configured and running on all Gentoo Infrastructure servers. Below are sample configuration settings for sysklogd:
body.pre:
# /etc/syslog.conf Configuration file for syslogd.
# # First some standard logfiles. Log by facility. #
auth,authpriv.* /var/log/auth.log *.*;auth,authpriv.none -/var/log/syslog cron.* /var/log/cron.log daemon.* -/var/log/daemon.log local6.* /var/log/rsync.log local4.* /var/log/ldap.log local3.* /var/log/xinetd.log Make sure that services such as rsyncd, xinetd and others are configured to use the localN log specified
# # Logging for the mail system. Split it up so that # it is easy to write scripts to parse these files. # mail.info -/var/log/mail.info mail.warn -/var/log/mail.warn mail.err /var/log/mail.err This section should be commented out for Gentoo mail servers since qmail and exim provide their own logging facilities.

body.p: We use logrotate to facilitate log rotations.
In general, log files should be kept around a minimum of 2 weeks, longer if disk space allows for it.
